title: Just the Two of Us
composer: Bill Withers / Ralph MacDonald / William Salter

musicalLanguage.description: The silky smooth jazz-soul classic built on one of the most beloved chord progressions in R&B: Dbmaj7-C7-Fm7-Ebm7-Ab7. This arrangement focuses on the lush chord voicings that define the song's character, with a gentle melodic line floating above. The Db major key gives it a rich, velvety warmth.
musicalLanguage.structure: The signature 4-chord vamp (4 bars) then melodic development over the same changes (4 bars)
keyMoments: Bar 1: Dbmaj7 — the lush opening. Pure silk.
Bar 2: C7 to Fm — the chromatic bass drop that makes this progression magical.
Bars 5-8: Melody takes center stage over the same chords — more ornamental.
teachingGoals: The classic 'Just the Two of Us' chord progression — used in hundreds of songs
Smooth voice leading between jazz chords
Playing melody over complex harmony without losing the groove
styleTips: Silky smooth — every chord change should melt into the next
Right hand melody should float above, never dig in
Left hand voices the chords gently — think Rhodes electric piano, not acoustic attack

measures.teachingNote: Dbmaj7 — rich and warm. Let every note ring.
C7 to Fm — the chromatic shift. E natural is the magic note.
Fm7 — minor color. The melody gently descends.
Ebm7 to Ab7 — the turnaround. Eb4 holds like a question mark.
Dbmaj7 — second pass, melody more active with eighth notes.
C7 — melody reaches up to Bb4 this time. More expressive.
Fm7 — smooth descent. Every note connects to the next.
Ebm7 to Ab7 — lands on F, pointing back to Db. The cycle continues.
